conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves backward.
A cylindrical container casting shadow A.
A green avocado casting shadow B.
An unknown object casting shadow C.
A waffle or waffle-like food item casting shadow D.
The cement/concrete surface has a crack running across it, and the objects are sitting on this surface.
When a light source moves farther away while remaining directly above objects, shadows become less defined/more diffuse, smaller, and shift closer to being directly beneath their respective objects.

premise: Shadow A is currently slightly offset from the cylindrical container.
conclusion: When the light moves backward, shadow A will become smaller, move closer to being directly beneath the container, and its edges will become less defined.

premise: Shadow B is currently offset from the avocado.
conclusion: When the light moves backward, shadow B will become smaller, move closer to being directly beneath the avocado, and become less defined.

premise: Shadow C is currently visible at the bottom left.
conclusion: When the light moves backward, shadow C will become smaller, move closer to being directly beneath its source object, and become less defined.

premise: Shadow D is currently offset from the waffle.
conclusion: When the light moves backward, shadow D will become smaller, move closer to being directly beneath the waffle, and become less defined.

When a light source moves farther away, the light rays become more parallel to each other, causing shadows to become smaller and more directly beneath their objects. The light source creates a less harsh shadow (more diffuse) when it's farther away.

premise: When the light source moves backward while remaining above the objects, all shadows will become smaller in size, move closer to being directly beneath their respective objects, and become less defined/more diffuse at their edges.
conclusion: A, B, C and D shift forward, moving beneath the objects, and become shorter and smaller.
